stem: Why would a developer choose to store source code in Cloud Source Repositories? (Select 2)
options/0/title: To have total control over the hosting infrastructure
options/0/rationale: Review the "Development in the cloud" lecture.
options/2/title: To keep code private to a Google Cloud project
options/3/title: It is the only way to access your source code in a repository.
options/3/rationale: Review the "Development in the cloud" lecture.

stem: Select the advantage of putting the event-driven components of your application into Cloud Functions.
options/0/title: In Cloud Functions, processing is always free of charge.
options/0/rationale: Review the "Development in the cloud" lecture.
options/1/title: Cloud Functions handles scaling these components seamlessly.
options/2/title: In Cloud Functions, code can be written in C# or C++.
options/2/rationale: Review the "Development in the cloud" lecture.
options/3/title: Cloud Functions eliminates the need to use a separate service to trigger application events.
options/3/rationale: Review the "Development in the cloud" lecture.

stem: Why might a Google Cloud customer choose to use Cloud Functions?
options/0/title: Cloud Functions is the primary way to run Node.js applications in Google Cloud.
options/0/rationale: Review the lecture "Development in the Cloud."
options/1/title: Their application contains event-driven code that they don't want to provision compute resources for.
options/2/title: Cloud Functions is a free service for hosting compute operations.
options/2/rationale: Review the lecture "Development in the Cloud."
options/3/title: Their application has a legacy monolithic structure that they want to separate into microservices.
options/3/rationale: Review the lecture "Development in the Cloud."

stem: Why might a Google Cloud customer choose to use Terraform?
options/0/title: Terraform can be used as a version-control system for your Google Cloud infrastructure layout.
options/0/rationale: Review the "Deployment: Infrastructure as code” lecture.
options/1/title: Terraform can be used as an infrastructure management system for Google Cloud resources.
options/2/title: Terraform can be used as an infrastructure management system for Kubernetes pods.
options/2/rationale: Review the lecture "Deployment: Infrastructure as code”.
options/3/title: Terraform can be used to enforce maximum resource utilization and spending limits on your Google Cloud resources.
options/3/rationale: Review the lecture "Deployment: Infrastructure as code”.
